column3: Design Methods for the Future that is NOW: Have Disruptive Technologies Disrupted Our Design Methodologies?
column12: Karen Holtzblatt, Ilpo Koskinen, Janaki Kumar, David Rondeau, John Zimmerman
column256: Responsive Design. Mobile First. Agile Development. Lean UX. Crowdsourcing. Machine Learning. In a world that has been disrupted by new technologies and approaches, what does it mean to do “front-end” or “user-centered design”? Are we relying on methods that are too rooted in the past? What techniques are succeeding and what changes do we need to be making? Do we need different data collected, different styles of prototyping, different design principles, and ways of structuring products or apps when building across multiple platforms? How will any changes in UCD techniques be received by current professionals as well as product managers and developers? This panel explores whether user research and design methods as we know them need to be radically overhauled, or some even eliminated.
column257: 1. Marcotte, E., Responsive Web Design; http://alistapart.com/article/responsive-web-design/; May 25, 2010. \ 2. Wroblewski, L.; Mobile First; A Book Apart; January 1, 2011, New York, NY, USA. \ 3. Cashmore, P.; Why 2013 Is the Year of Responsive Web Design; http://mashable.com/2012/12/11/responsive-webdesign; December 11, 2012. \ 4. Holtzblatt, K. “What makes things cool?: Intentional design for innovation”, Interactions, Volume 18 Issue 6, November + December 2011, pp 40-47. \ 5. Howe, J.; The Rise of Crowdsourcing; WIRED Magazine; June 2006. \ 6. Simon, P., Crowdsourcing Design: An Interview with DesignCrowd Founder Alec Lynch; http://www.huffingtonpost.com/philsimon/crowdsourcing-design-an-i_b_4179653.html; October 30, 2013. \ 7. Gothfelf, J.; Lean UX: Applying Lean Principles to Improve User Experience; O'Reilly Media; February 22, 2013. \ 8. Dylan, B; The Times They Are a-Changin’; The Times They Are a-Changin'; Columbia Records; January 1964. \
column258: Cross-platform design; design methods; front-end design; innovation; Lean UX; product design; prototyping; requirements gathering; responsive design; service design
column264: This panel discusses what is means to do user-centered design in a world that has been that has been disrupted by new technologies and approaches.
column265: Our original proposal had Johan Redstrom of as an unconfirmed panelist. Johan was unable to participate so we have confirmed in his place Ilpo Koskinen, professor of industrial design at Aalto University. Ilpo will bring a multi-national perspective to our panel. We appreciate the suggestion to include a panelist from the start-up world or from Google which has been pushing the mobile-first approach. However, we were unable to find a confirmed panelist in the short amount of time available to do so. However, several panelists have experience designing for mobile devices and will bring that to the panel. Panelists also have experience working with Agile development and integrating UX into Agile processes. Finally, we will be sure to talk about how the various methods have been adopted and modified for use.  \

column12: Helena M. Mentis, Kristina Höök, Florian Mueller, Katherine Isbister, George Poonkhin Khut, Toni Robertson
column13: mentis@umbc.edu, kia@sics.se, floyd@floydmueller.com, isbister@poly.edu, georgekhut@gmail.com, toni@it.uts.edu.au
column65: Polytechnic Institute of New York University
column80: Interaction Design and Human Practice Lab, University of Technology Sydney

column12: Juan Pablo Hourcade, Ann Cavoukian, Ronald Deibert, Lorrie Faith Cranor, Ian Goldberg
column35: Office of the Information and Privacy Commissioner of Ontario
column256: The confluence of big data, data analytics, and connected devices is facilitating electronic surveillance and compromising privacy in unprecedented ways. This panel brings together voices with a diverse set of experiences and interests to discuss electronic privacy and surveillance, and the contributions the human-computer interaction community can make in this arena. Topics will include the usability of privacy tools, how to design interactive technologies with privacy as a primary consideration while incorporating user-centered design practices, and how to manage the technical complexity involved in privacy tools while enabling users to make wise choices.

column3: Can You Do Good and Do Well? Exploring HCI Careers for Societal Impact
column12: Anupam Jain, Matthew Kam, Michael Best, Elizabeth M Gerber, Rowena Luk
column49: Sam Nunn School of International Affairs and School of Interactive Computing
column256: International development and initiatives towards societal impact have been slowly gaining momentum in the HCI forums over the last few years. A subset of HCI researchers and practitioners worldwide have been working to design, build, evaluate and deploy solutions for the 80% of the world which lives on less than $10 a day[2] and broadly for humanitarian efforts that improves people’s lives at large. However, a large section of the HCI community is still not directly involved in this space even if they are interested, because of concerns like job uncertainty, lack of awareness of avenues to help, time availability and perhaps some delusions about the space. This panel brings together panelists who are HCI professionals trying to produce social impact from four different domains (non-profit, for-profit social enterprise, academic research and corporate research) and are from different geographies and stages in their careers. . The panel explores how HCI researchers and practitioners can consider HCI-related careers in international development and other societal impact initiatives, introduce the CHI community to different means through which they could make meaningful contributions, discuss why it may be imminent for HCI specialists to apply their expertise to this space, cite and discuss some real world stories and try to answer as many queries from people who would like to get involved either as volunteers or for full-time careers.
column257: 1. Kam, M., Dray, S., Toyama, K., Marsden G., Parikh T., Cutrell E., Computing Technology in International Development: Who, What, Where, When, Why and How?. CHI 2010, Extended Abstracts on Human Factors in Computing Systems, Pages 3135-3138. \ 2. Workshop at CHI 2008, Florence, Italy, April 2008. \ 6. Ho, M.R, Smyth, T.N, Kam, M., Deardon, A., Human Computer Interaction for Development: The Past, Present and Future. Information Technologies and International Development, Vol 5, Issue 4, Winter 2009. \ 7. Pal, J. et. al., Starting an academic research career in ICTD, ICTD 2013, Cape Town, South Africa. \ 8. Grameen Foundation, Dec 2013. http://www.grameenfoundation.org/blog/gettingready-career-social-enterprise. \
column258: Social impact; HCI4D; International Development; ICTD; Non Profits; Social Enterprise; HCI career
column263: Making the world a better place
column264: Always wanted to lend a hand but looking for a start? HCI professionals working towards societal impact discuss the challenges, the rewards and the need. More action at http://chi2014.wikispaces.com/dogood !
column265: Thanks for the feedback! About reviewers' concern on the regional focus, we are very interested in exploring development careers across both geographies (developed and developing nations) and have panelists representing both of these. We agree to the reviewers' suggestions on making the topic a bit broader to cover societal-impact \ initiatives in general (including urban but under-represented communities \ and also fields like medicine, accessibility etc.) and have revamped the content and the topic to reflect such intent. The "do well" part has now been referred to at two different places with example. We also have interest from another panelist at thereboot.org who perfectly fits in the broader vision of societal impact initiatives but cannot add her due to space constraints (5 panelists already including the moderator). But if we discover later that any of the existing panelists cannot make it for any inevitable reason, then we could include thereboot's participation provided the chairs are ok with that.

column3: Making Cultures: Empowerment, Participation, and Democracy – or Not?
column12: Morgan G Ames, Jeffrey Bardzell, Shaowen Bardzell, Silvia Lindtner, David A Mellis, Daniela K Rosner
column13: morganya@gmail.com, jbardzel@indiana.edu, selu@indiana.edu, silvia.lindtner@gmail.com, mellis@media.mit.edu, dkrosner@uw.edu
column256: Making has transformed from a fringe and hobbyist practice into a professionalizing field and an emerging industry. Enthusiasts laud its potential to democratize technology, improve the workforce, empower consumers, encourage citizen science, and contribute to the global economy. Yet critics counter that in the West, making often remains a hobby for the privileged and seems to be increasingly co-opted by corporate interests. This panel brings together HCI scholars and practitioners active in making, handwork, DIY, crafts, and tool design to examine and debate the visions that come from maker cultures.

column264: A panel of researchers and practitioners, who are active in making, handwork, DIY, crafts, and tool design, explores issues concerning maker cultures.
column265: - Reduced the panel size, per the request of the Chairs. \  \ - Rewrote the panel description to reflect the change.  \  \ - Removed the first of the two panel questions identified by reviewers as weak (this was the question on why making is so popular) \  \ - Revised and clarified the second of the two panel questions identified by reviewers as weak (the question more clearly gets at what we do think is important, which is who is included and who is excluded from making). The revised version now reads: "Who is “in” and who is “out” of the maker movement, and why?" \  \ - Added an acknowledgements section at the end of the proposal to reflect the contributions of two panelists who had to bow out.

column3: CROWDFUNDING: An Emerging Field of Research
column12: Elizabeth M Gerber, Michael Muller, Rick Wash, Lilly C Irani, Amanda Williams, Elizabeth F Churchill
column13: egerber@northwestern.edu, michael_muller@us.ibm.com, wash@msu.edu, lirani@ucsd.edu, amanda@fabule.com, churchill@acm.org
column256: Crowdfunding, the request of resources through social media, has generated much discussion in the popular press; however, there have been few systematic empirical studies of this growing phenomenon. We bring together the leading HCI researchers in crowdfunding and crowdsourcing to discuss this potentially transformative socio-technical innovation that may advance (or harm) human capabilities to innovate and collaborate.  We will discuss current empirical research on crowdfunding and the future of research in this field from diverse perspectives including computer science, social science, communications, and design, using both qualitative and quantitative research methods.  To make real progress towards realizing future research, we will lead a discussion with the audience of new research agendas in crowdfunding.

column258: Crowdfunding; Enterprise crowdfunding; Qualitative Methods; Quantitative Methods; Digital divide
column264: Crowdfunding is growing in popularity; however, few systematic empirical studies of this phenomenon exist. Leading HCI researchers in crowdfunding will gather to discuss the future of research in this area.
column265: We have taken all of the ACs suggestions for improvement. \  \ In our revisions, our primary goal was to expand the perspectives included on the panel and include a more critical view of crowdfunding.   \  \ Most importantly, we expanded the panel to include two HCI researchers and designers: Lilly Irani and Amanda Williams.  Lilly's work is concerned with how such work is affecting labor markets - understanding who benefits and who does not.  As a female tech entrepreneur, Amanda provides first hand experience with crowdfunding as she tried to raise money to manufacture her robot. She identifies the opportunities and challenges for supporting tech and the limited number of alternatives for tech entrepreneurs. \  \ Additionally, we have adjusted the research questions to examine both the ways in which crowdfunding can create opportunities for some and limit opportunities for other. \  \ We have also modified the question concerned with methodology to include a broader discussion of the different ways we might approach this research, the benefits and disadvantages of such approaches, and the availability of data. \  \ Thank you again to the great suggestions for improvement!

column3: The Meaning of Design in Healthcare: Industry, Academia, Visual Design, Clinician, Patient and HF Consultant Perspectives
column12: Svetlena Taneva, Waxberg Sara, Goss Julian, Rossos Peter, Nicholas Emily, Cafazzo Joseph
column13: svetlena@humanfactors.ca, sara.waxberg@philips.com, jgoss@faculty.ocadu.ca, Peter.Rossos@uhn.ca, emily.nicholas@patientsassociation.ca, joe@humanfactors.ca
column34: Philips Healthcare, Andover, Massachusetts, United States
column49: Ontario College of Art and Design University , Toronto, Ontario, Canada
column64: University Health Network, Toronto, Ontario, Canada
column94: Healthcare Human Factors, Toronto, Ontario, Canada
column256: Healthcare technologies have a reputation for being overly-complex, difficult-to-use, uninspired, and unusable. There is a significant opportunity to incorporate human-centered design into healthcare through the synthesis of deep healthcare domain expertise, visual and industrial design, human factors theory and practice, and an understanding of the patient experience. In practice, the need for such synthesis brings together professionals who often have distinct understanding of the meaning of design in healthcare and the ways in which design can solve problems in healthcare. As such, each professional encounters distinct challenges in trying to realize good design in healthcare. This panel will bring together the contrasting perspectives of industry, academia, visual design, clinicians, patients, and human factors consultants on the role of user interface and technology design in healthcare. Each representative speaker will share his/her experience, lessons learned, and thoughts on the role and meaning of design in healthcare. The audience will then be engaged in a discussion that aims to bring a common understanding, inclusive of all perspectives.

column265: We thank the reviewers for the constructive comments. We have revised the submission to improve the readability. In response to the main concern regarding the predominantly Canadian representation in the choice of panelists, we discussed the suggestion to replace at least one panel member. We concluded that it will be difficult to find a new panelist in the short time frame. The main consideration was that the panel brings together professionals, most of whom do not usually attend the CHI conference (e.g. a clinician, a patient, a medical technology vendor representative). The conference travel and registration requirement to participate is a barrier to securing the presence of such panelists from other countries. Having said that, we would like to emphasize that one of our panelists is from the U.S. (Sara Waxberg) and two other panelists (Joseph Cafazzo and Svetlena Taneva)regularly work on international consulting projects with global companies based on different continents and evaluating their product designs around the globe. In addition, we will strongly encourage the international audience at CHI to contribute their perspectives during the panel. Hence, we are confident that the panel will be able to bring out the challenges and perspectives encountered internationally.

column3: Opportunities and Risks of Discovering Personality Traits from Social Media
column12: Michelle X. Zhou, Jeffrey Nichols, Tom Dignan, Steve Lohr, Jennifer Golbeck, James W Pennebaker
column13: mzhou@us.ibm.com, jwnichols@us.ibm.com, tom.dignan@reputation.com, lohr@nytimes.com, golbeck@cs.umd.edu, pennebaker@mail.utexas.edu
column95: The University of Texas at Austin
column256: With the emergence of social media and the availability of big data, there has been much interest in mining the digital footprints left by users to predict personality traits (e.g., introvert and idealistic) and gain a deeper understanding of individuals. While such understanding will enable hyper-personalized computing, such as  \ personality-based marketing, the use of this technology will have far-reaching social implications that could affect almost every aspect of our lives. For example, personality traits mined from social media could be used to guide hiring and promotion decisions or decide who is admitted into top academic programs. The risks of using derived personality traits are potentially high, particular due to factors such as the veracity of data collected from social media, imperfections in prediction algorithms, and a lack of control over how, when, and to whom anyone’s personality traits might be exposed. We will use this panel to bring together experts from the fields of Psychology, Social Science, Computer Science, along with the CHI community, to discuss and debate the opportunities and risks of personality discovery from social media and the implications on technical communities and our society at large.   \

column265: Based on the reviews, we have revised our submission to address two main concerns: \  \ (1) We have finalized all four of our panelists.  \  \ Steve Lohr, a Senior Writer and Technology Reporter from New York Times, will be on the privacy aspect since danah boyd does not attend CHI. As shown by Steve's bio, he has been publishing articles and conducting interviews on the topic of privacy.  Given his journalist background, we believe he will bring some of very refreshing and insightful views on our subject. In addition,  this panel could potentially be become one of his Sunday columns appearing in NY Times. Such publicity and result will definitely help extend the reach of this area of work as well as for CHI.  \  \ Tom Dignan, who leads the technology development at Reputation.com, will be on the use of such technologies and their implications in real-world consumer systems. Since Michael Fertik could not make it not mentioning that his appearance also requires a high fee that we could not afford. So he recommended Tom who actually leads the company in building the internet-scale online consumer reputation system. He is also a veteran on the subject of protecting consumer privacy while helping people build their online brands and reputation.  \  \ Overall, we are very excited and feel lucky that Steve and Tom are able to join us on our panel as we believe the combined background and experience of our panelists will really make our panel unique and interesting! \  \ (2) We have added concrete details on the panel format and structure. Since now we have the full panel, we described in the revised proposal, what each panelist will talk about and which area of questions they will focus on addressing and interacting with the audience. In addition, we also decided to use the introduction to show brief live demos (e.g., using the audience IDs) to show the feasibility of the current technology and engage the audience  from the start of the panel.  \  \ Overall, thank you again for your review and support! We believe the topic along with the panelists we have, we will have a very exciting and inspiring event that many of our CHI audience will enjoy and find valuable! \  \  \  \
